ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed skills of analyzing music and lyric within opera, learned about the operatic tradition and how it transformed over time, and read selections from influential philosophers during the time periods of the first productions of the operas.
Learned the history behind some of the most important operas in the Western tradition, as well the intellectual basis on which they were composed; practiced writing philosophy and music
I learned a great deal about opera, its history, and its philosophical context. I learned how to analyze opera's musical, intellectual, and organizational themes.
I developed my musical ear and was able to connect music to its environment/setting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We were able to survey a larger history of opera and operatic trends while simultaneously delving deeply into four operas. Overall a very strong course.

Strength: Well-chosen operas/readings and papers were designed to be open-ended; Professor Tomlinson is very engaging and highly knowledgeable; I enjoyed the focus on the music itself, but this could be a weakness for those more interested in the philosophy Weakness: Nothing major, I personally found the lecture setup to be conducive to the course, though some might prefer a seminar style

Strengths: This course was well-organized & engaging. The workload was relatively even throughout the term. Weaknesses: Occasionally the reading/viewing assignments were unclear or not fully updated. There could have been a bit more direct student engagement in class with the readings.

Extremely engaging, I especially liked when Prof. Tomlinson would play the piano in class and point out aspects of the musical structure. I wish he also went a bit more in depth technically with the music, even though it may go over some peoples' heads, I think quick technical comments would have been fascinating.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially for a humanities major or any student interested in music and music analysis.

Yes, for sure, especially if they are interested in opera, less so if they are interested in philosophy. I enjoyed writing the papers and thought the feedback was helpful, though some may find that the writing style is different than that for other writing-heavy courses, so plan accordingly

I would 100% recommend this class to other students! This course was amazing! Professor Tomlinson is an engaging teacher, and you will have a blast learning about opera, its history, and its philosophical context. This is not a gut class--you will have to put in the work--but it is a rewarding experience that everyone at Yale should take.
